questions.title: Connection Pool (LLD)
questions.prompt: Implement a connection pool. Requirements: (1) Pool size is fixed (1000-2000 connections). (2) Developers can `requestConnection()` and `releaseConnection()`. (3) If a connection is closed by the developer, create a new one to maintain the pool count. (4) Connection states: FREE, BLOCKED, CLOSED. (5) Implement a default timeout - if no connection is freed within the timeout, reject the request.
followups: How do you handle concurrent requests for connections?
You used a BlockingQueue. What is the time complexity of checking the status of a connection?
How would you scale this to millions of connections?
The interviewer pushed back on O(n) status checking. How would you achieve O(1)?
How do you prevent a connection from being returned twice?

questions.title: LRU Cache Design
questions.prompt: Design and implement an LRU (Least Recently Used) cache. Implement `get(key)` and `put(key, value)` in O(1) average time. The keys and values can be of generic/dynamic data types.
followups: Why do you need both a HashMap and a Doubly Linked List?
How do you handle concurrency?
How would you implement this using generics/templates?
What is the space complexity?

questions.title: Array Reduction (Passes to Sort)
questions.prompt: Given an array, on each pass you remove an element at index `i` if `arr[i-1] >= arr[i]`. Calculate the number of passes required before the array becomes strictly increasing.
followups: What is the brute force O(n²) approach?
How can you optimize this using a stack or linked list simulation?
What data structure allows efficient removal of elements?
What edge cases (empty array, already increasing) need to be handled?

questions.title: Reconstruct Itinerary (No Cycles)
questions.prompt: You are given a list of airline tickets represented as `[from, to]`. There are no loops or multiple paths. Reconstruct the itinerary in order. If there are multiple valid itineraries, return the one with the smallest lexical order.
followups: How do you represent the graph?
Why is a hierarchical DFS necessary?
What is the time complexity?

questions.title: Count Palindromes of Size K
questions.prompt: Given a binary array consisting of only 1s and 0s, find the number of palindromic subarrays of size exactly 5.
followups: What is the brute force O(n*k) approach?
How can you optimize palindrome checking using prefix hashing?
How would you generalize this to any odd-sized palindrome?

questions.title: Binary Heap / Priority Queue Implementation
questions.prompt: You are given a problem that is optimally solved using a binary heap. Implement a min-heap from scratch. The interviewer probed you to reduce complexity to O(log n).
followups: What is the underlying data structure for a binary heap?
How do you implement `heapifyUp()` and `heapifyDown()`?
What is the time complexity of building a heap from an array?

questions.title: Maximum Frequency Stack
questions.prompt: Implement `FreqStack` that supports `push(int val)`, `pop()`, and `popMax()` (pop the most frequent element).
followups: How do you maintain the frequency of each element?
How do you maintain a stack per frequency level?
What is the time complexity of each operation?

questions.title: Scalability & Database Sharding
questions.prompt: When would you choose to shard a database? What are the complexities introduced by sharding?
followups: Why would you be 'scared' of sharding?
What are the trade-offs between vertical and horizontal scaling?
How do you choose a shard key?
How do you handle cross-shard joins or transactions?

questions.title: High Latency API Debugging
questions.prompt: Your API endpoint has suddenly become slow. What is your systematic approach to diagnosing and fixing the issue?
followups: What tools do you use to profile the application?
How do you identify if it's a CPU, I/O, or database bottleneck?
How do you implement tracing to find the slow downstream dependency?

questions.title: Idempotency in APIs
questions.prompt: What is idempotency and why is it important in distributed systems? How would you implement an idempotent POST endpoint?
followups: What is the difference between idempotent and safe methods?
How do you generate and store idempotency keys?
What is the TTL for an idempotency key and why?

questions.title: SOLID Principles Deep Dive
questions.prompt: Explain the SOLID principles in detail. Provide an example of how violating Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP) causes bugs.
followups: What happens if we don't follow the Single Responsibility Principle?
Give a classic example of LSP violation (e.g., Square-Rectangle).
How do interfaces help achieve Dependency Inversion?

questions.title: JWT Authentication Flow
questions.prompt: How does JWT (JSON Web Token) authentication work? What are the security considerations?
followups: What is the difference between JWT and server-side sessions?
How do you handle token revocation?
Where should you store JWTs on the client side?

questions.title: When and Why Not to Use Indexes?
questions.prompt: You have a slow query. Adding an index is the obvious solution. Why and when would you choose NOT to add an index?
followups: What are the trade-offs of adding too many indexes?
How do indexes affect write performance?
What is index cardinality and why does it matter?

questions.title: Design a Feature Delivery Pipeline
questions.prompt: Walk me through a time you delivered a feature from start to finish. How did you ensure quality and timely delivery?
followups: How did you gather requirements?
What was your testing strategy?
How did you handle feedback during the review process?

questions.title: Binary Tree Maximum Path Sum
questions.prompt: Given the root of a binary tree, return the maximum path sum of any non-empty path. (A path does not need to pass through the root.)
followups: What information needs to be returned from each recursive call?
How do you handle negative values?
What is the time complexity of your solution?

questions.title: Top K Frequent Elements
questions.prompt: Given an integer array `nums` and an integer `k`, return the `k` most frequent elements. You may return the answer in any order.
followups: What is the time complexity of the heap approach (O(n log k))?
How does bucket sort achieve O(n) time?
What if `k` is close to `n`?

questions.title: Number of Islands
questions.prompt: Given an `m x n` 2D binary grid `grid` which represents '1's (land) and '0's (water), return the number of islands.
followups: What is the space complexity of DFS vs BFS?
How would you solve this if the grid is too large to fit in memory?
How do you handle diagonal connections?

questions.title: Course Schedule (Cycle Detection)
questions.prompt: There are `numCourses` courses labeled from `0` to `numCourses-1`. You are given `prerequisites` where `prerequisites[i] = [a, b]` indicates you must take course `b` before course `a`. Determine if you can finish all courses.
followups: How do you detect a cycle in a directed graph?
Compare Kahn's algorithm (BFS) vs DFS for topological sort.
How would you return the order of courses?

questions.title: Longest Increasing Subsequence
questions.prompt: Given an integer array `nums`, return the length of the longest strictly increasing subsequence.
followups: What is the O(n²) DP recurrence?
How does patience sorting achieve O(n log n)?
How would you reconstruct the actual subsequence?

questions.title: Knapsack (0/1) Problem
questions.prompt: Given a list of items with weights and values, and a knapsack capacity, determine the maximum value you can carry.
followups: What is the DP state and transition?
How do you optimize space to O(capacity)?
How would you handle fractional items (greedy)?

questions.title: Operating Systems: Process Scheduling
questions.prompt: Explain different CPU scheduling algorithms. Which one minimizes waiting time? Which one minimizes response time?
followups: What is the difference between preemptive and non-preemptive scheduling?
How does the Round Robin algorithm work?
What is starvation and how do you prevent it?
